awd_titl_txt: NRI: Large: Collaborative Research: Human-robot Coordinated Manipulation and Transportation of Large Objects
awd_abstract_narration:
Motivated by the complementary abilities of humans and humanoids, the objective of this proposal is to develop the science and technology necessary for realizing human-robot cooperative object manipulation and transportation. The key concepts that this research seeks to promote are adaptability to human activity under minimal communication, and robustness to variability and uncertainty in the environment, achieved through a layered representation and deliberate processing of the available information. Moreover, this project aims to make maximum use of a minimal set of sensors to plan and control the actions of the robot, while ensuring safe and efficient cooperative transportation.  The embodiment of this research is a humanoid co-worker that bears most of the load, when helping a person to carry an object, without requiring excessive communication, or prior training on the part of the human.

By introducing concrete methods for human-robot physical collaboration in semi-structured environments, this project enables a unique synergy between robots and humans that has the potential to increase productivity, and reduce accidents and injuries. In doing so, it also promotes the advancement of new practical applications of robots in construction, manufacturing, logistics, and home services. By developing open-source, portable algorithms for humanoid robots and mobile manipulators, this effort results in cost and time savings for researchers, developers, educators, and end-users in robotics. Finally, through an aggressive educational and community outreach plan, and by actively engaging K-12 students in an exciting RoboTech Fellows program, this project seeks to increase diversity and attract underrepresented groups to STEM.

por.por_cntn:
Motivated by the complementary abilities of humans and humanoid robots, the main goal of this project has been to develop the science and technology necessary for realizing human-robot cooperative object manipulation and transportation. The key concepts that this research seeks to promote are adaptability to human activity under minimal communication, and robustness to variability and uncertainty in the environment, achieved through a layered representation and deliberate processing of the available information. This project pursued novel directions in addressing the following challenging problems: (i) Determining the state of the robot and the environment within which it operates; (ii) Estimating the person’s posture and predicting her motion throughout the manipulation and transportation task; (iii) Devising grasping and manipulation algorithms that explicitly incorporate the physical interaction of the robot with the human to achieve truly cooperative behaviors while ensuring safety; (iv) Synthesizing bipedal locomotion controllers that use information about the robot’s state and the human’s motion to guarantee stable and reliable object manipulation and transportation; (v) Introducing efficient motion planning techniques to navigate in human-centric, semi-structured environments, while avoiding collisions with static and moving obstacles; (vi) Improving safety by proactively avoiding hazardous configurations, detecting imminent dangers and reacting to unforeseen events.

Our activity on locomotion controllers aimed at providing algorithms that enable dynamically stable bipedal robots to navigate in human-centric environments while physically collaborating with a human to transport an object. In our work, we model human-humanoid interaction through an external force applied to the robot at the port of interaction with the human. We assume that this force carries information about the desired trajectory of the object to be transported, and that this trajectory is known only to the human; the robot merely senses the force applied by the human leader without explicit knowledge of the intended trajectory. We treat this interaction force as a command signal, and we design feedback control laws that utilize switching among a collection of dynamic movement primitives to adapt the robot’s locomotion pattern while offering provable safety guarantees. To realize natural, op-tempo, human-humanoid collaboration, we focus on dynamically-stable walking motions, in which – as is the case for humans – the robot continuously falls and captures itself resulting in limit-cycle walking gaits. The proposed locomotion control policies can (i) accommodate the dynamic constraints induced by the coordinated manipulation task, (ii) adapt to variations of the physical and geometric properties of the environment, and (iii) attenuate irregularities associated with the human’s motion. Therefore, our locomotion control synthesis framework can be used to enable bipedal robots to be responsive to the human collaborator’s intentions while supporting safe and reliable cooperative manipulation and object transportation.


Last Modified: 02/14/2020
Modified by: Ioannis Poulakakis
